subtitle: This steamed suet pudding should finish off the largest appetites.

method.text: Use most of the butter to grease the base and sides of a 1 <sup>1</sup>/<sub>5</sub> litre pudding basin. Press half the raisins against the butter to form a 'crust'.
Mix all the remaining ingredients for the pudding together - except for the remaining butter. Then spoon into the basin and smooth over the surface.

Spread the reserved butter over greaseproof paper and cover the pudding with this. Cover with foil, tying securely around the edge to prevent water from getting in. Place on a trivet in a saucepan and pour in enough boiling water to come two thirds of the way up the side of the basin.
Steam over boiling water for 1 hour 45 min, checking the water level frequently and topping up if necessary.
To make the sauce: Pare the rind from the lemon, taking care to use only the top layer of rind and none of the bitter white pith. Squeeze out the juice.
Put the rind into a saucepan with the water. Cover the pan and simmer gently for 10 min. Strain the liquid and return to the pan with the lemon juice and sugar.
Blend the cornflour with the wine or water. Add to the pan and stir over a low heat until the mixture has thickened to the desired consistency.
Turn the pudding out onto a warmed serving plate. Top with a little of the sauce and serve the rest separately in a jug.

title: Citrus suet pudding
